Authors: Liliana M Davalos, Eliecer E Gutierrez, Paul M Velazco
Title:
MITOCHONDRIAL CYTOCHROME B GENE PHYLOGENIES OF BATS: THE
GOOD, THE BAD, AND THE DIFFICULT
Keywords:
Chiroptera; Cytochrome b; homoplasy; phylogeny;
saturation; systematic error; third positions
Abstract:
Background: Single-gene phylogenies will continue to be
used as species trees because most populations are rare and lack sources
of high quality genomic DNA, and few loci overlap across many taxa for
comparative analyses. We analyze a recently compiled matrix of
mitochondrial cytochrome b (cytb) gene sequences of bats to uncover
systematic error from base composition bias superimposed on rapidly
evolving sites whose phylogenetic signal is random with respect to
phylogeny. Partitioned likelihood analyses of support for incorrect
nodes were used to locate the codon positions responsible for
significant homoplasy. Results: Partitioned cytb sequences inferred a
well-supported phylogeny of most genera, with low support for older
divergences. In contrast with previous Platalina was recovered as a
phyllostomid and not a vespertilionid; and Phyllostomidae,
Vespertilionidae, Emballonura, and Myotis were each monophyletic. The
non-monophyly of mormoopids, Pipistrellus, and Eptesicus was traced to
third positions, which were saturated and heterogeneous in their base
composition. These spurious relationships were recovered even when using
RY coding, or coding third positions as a binary character. The sister
relationship of Taphozous and Miniopterus was traced to second
positions. Conclusions: Rapidly evolving third codon positions are
vulnerable to signal from genome-wide changes in base composition, and
there is evidence of natural selection on protein function resulting in
spurious nodes supported by second positions. Phylogenetic analyses of
large, ancient clades such as bats must consider the effects of both
non-selective and selective forces in shaping the phylogenetic signal of
any one gene and, whenever possible, account for homoplasy when seeking
to resolve the phylogeny with a single locus.
